In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/zambia)

name: In Zambia, of all children age
questionText: In Zambia, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2017?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [Source: UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR?locations=ZM)

name: How much of Zambia is barren l
questionText: How much of Zambia is barren land, with bare soil, sand and rocks?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). It defines barren land as "any geographical area dominated by natural abiotic surfaces (bare soil, sand, rocks, etc.) where the natural vegetation is absent or nearly absent (i.e. cover is less than 2 per cent). The class includes areas regularly flooded by inland water (lake shores, river banks, salt flats, etc.). It excludes coastal areas
affected by the tidal movement of saltwater." It compiles this information from publicly available maps from two different sources of satellite data. It is hard to define land completely accurately and that is why we have big differences between our answer options and don't give a precise number, choosing instead to use "less than" or "around".

Source link: [FAO](http://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/LC/visualize)

name: How many babies in Zambia were
questionText: How many babies in Zambia were vaccinated against some disease in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [WHO & UNICEF](https://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/countries?countrycriteria%5Bcountry%5D%5B%5D=ZMB)

name: Of all the primary school teac
questionText: Of all the primary school teachers in Zambia, how many have had teacher training?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from UNESCO. When it comes to issues around this data, one is that there is no global definition for what constitutes an academically trained teacher so each country has a slightly different definition. Also, a trained teacher is not necessarily the same as a qualified teacher. Plus, national standards regarding teacher qualifications and pedagogical skills may vary. This means estimates are dependent on the policy of each country and affect the final number.  The variable does not take into account the varying experience and status of teachers or how they were trained and what they have at their disposal when teaching (materials, classroom conditions etc) which are all factors that affect the quality of teaching and learning. Finally, some teachers without formal training may have acquired equivalent pedagogical skills through professional experience. Despite these concerns, three independent experts we contacted say they trust this data. We also try to counter these caveats by putting large differences between the answer options. 

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TCAQ.ZS?locations=ZM)

name: How many adults in Uganda say
questionText: How many adults in Uganda say they can read and write?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Literacy data is from UNESCO. Data quality varies between countries and generally it is less reliable in low-income countries. 
It has been collected using different methodologies in different countries. In some countries the people surveyed are asked if they can read a short text aloud. In many countries, though, people are just asked if they can read or sometimes only if they and the people they live with went to school. There is some evidence from studies that people do not read as well as they report themselves to and that, in some cases, going to school may not mean a person is what we might consider to be literate. These doubts should not stop us recognizing the overall trend, that more mem, women and children have more years of education and more people say they can read than ever before. 
We have put big differences between our three answer options to ensure our correct answer is more correct than the other two.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.LITR.ZS?locations=UG)

name: What was the life expectancy i
questionText: What was the life expectancy in Uganda in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Life expectancy is the number of years the average newborn in a population can expect to live if mortality rates in that year continue for the rest of a person’s life. For this question, we have used data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)'s 2019 Global Burden of Disease Study, which are estimates. This data is not collected annually (usually once every 10 years or so) and, as such, some of the countries’ figures may be slightly outdated. If data were available for every country for this year it is quite likely the average life expectancy would be even higher. 

Source link: [IHME](http://ihmeuw.org/5cy0)

name: How many firms in Togo use ema
questionText: How many firms in Togo use email to interact with clients or suppliers?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we use data from the Enterprise Survey by the World Bank. This is based on interviews conducted during the period 2009 to 2020 with tens of thousands of businesses with 5 or more employees in the manufacturing and service sectors in 144 countries. Firms with 100% government/state ownership are not included. The number of businesses per country ranges from 150 in small countries, to nearly 2000 in large countries. Because the data is based on a small sample of all companies in the world, there is a large margin of error which we take into consideration by putting big differences between the correct answer and the two wrong options. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://tcdata360.worldbank.org/indicators/etrade.pct.email?country=TGO&indicator=272&viz=bar_chart&years=2016)

name: How much of Togo is protected
questionText: How much of Togo is protected land, such as national parks?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This is a trickier thing to measure that it might forst appear. The source we use (Protected Planet) is a good respresentation of what land is designated as protected by governments but the problem is countries choose which land they decide to protect. This can end up being ‘the land that nobody wants’ that they protect just to meet targets. There’s also no evidence that countries spend any more time, money or effort, conserving this land (which is sort of the point). It can become more of an exercise in box ticking than conservation, which is why we have avoided asking questions about countries where we know there to be particular issues.

Source link: [Protected Planet](https://www.protectedplanet.net/country/TGO)

name: In South Sudan, 41% of the pop
questionText: In South Sudan, 41% of the population are younger than 15 years. What do UN experts expect it to be in 2050?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question, we use projections from the UN Population Division which published new 
population forecasts every second year in their publication World Population Prospects. They work with multiple alternative scenarios. The one they think is most probable is called the ‘medium fertility variant’, which falls between the highest and lowest predictions of fertility and mortality decline worldwide. For the past ten years, the UN Population Division has published forecasts of this scenario predicting that the number of children in the year 2100 will not be higher than it is today. In their latest revision published in 2019, the UN Population Division estimates that there are 1.975 billion children (aged 0 to 14) in 2019 and forecast that the number will be 1.898 billion in 2100 (having peaked at 2.06 in the year 2053). Nobody can know for sure, but the question is only asking which forecast is the most likely. 

Source link: [UN](https://population.un.org/wpp/)

name: How much of all the money earn
questionText: How much of all the money earned in South Africa comes from agriculture, forestry and fishing?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The share of the world’s economy which is made up of agriculture, fishing and forestry is only 5%, because almost all money made today comes from services and manufacturing. This is based on national accounts data which is of poorer quality in poorer countries where the informal sector is larger. Over the last 200 years, most countries increased their incomes and as they did they have followed very similar declines of agriculture as a share of their economies. It’s hard to know exactly what the global percentage was at the start of the industrial revolution, but probably around 50%. That’s where a few extremely poor countries still are today.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS?locations=ZA)

name: How many babies in South Afric
questionText: How many babies in South Africa were born with a trained health worker present, before the pandemic?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This data is complied by the World Health Organization and Unicef. The number we use is based on the most recent data. Data from some countries is more reliable than from others. Different countries also use very different criteria for what is a “trained” health worker. To account for this we use the correct option “more than” rather than using a specific number, to ensure we do not overestimate progress. Since 2004, we have known how many skilled health workers attend births but not their quality. After 2004, there was an increase in births attended by skilled workers, and even though there was a lot of progress, the decline in maternal mortality didn’t reach the 75% by 2015 that was stated in the Millennium Development Goals (The decrease in maternal mortality ratio from 2000 to 2017 was 38%. This was addressed in 2018, with a newer definition of who is a skilled health worker, which has stricter standards. Our data doesn’t yet take this new definition into account as most of the data was collected before 2018. Due to the issue around the definition of “skilled” we tweaked the question to say “trained” health worker instead, as the definition the data uses still meets that criteria.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://data.unicef.org/topic/maternal-health/delivery-care/)

name: During the past 5 years, women
questionText: During the past 5 years, women held 25% of all seats in national parliaments worldwide. What was the number in South Africa?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Our correct figure is an average across both lower and upper chambers of parliament between 2017-2022. This figure will change as elections are held. We chose to have an average across both chambers of parliament despite the upper houses having different levels of power in different countries. It’s worth noting that being represented in the parliament does not automatically transfer into female contribution and engagement as there sometimes can be other obstacles.
We consulted six independent experts for this question who all agreed that the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) data is extremely reliable.

Source link: [IPU](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QE30QKC-uMbvUlYxLDaZpTVe59ooO0Rz9IC-dbIDQJg/edit#gid=569008175)

name: How many UNESCO world heritage
questionText: How many UNESCO world heritage sites are found in South Africa?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
These figures come directly from UNESCO. It is important to recognize that the UNESCO system of designating world heritage sites is not without controversy. Firstly, there are accustions of favoritism and that poorer countries struggle to have their sites recognized due to a lack of expertize. Next, there is an accusation that it can be used to profit from people's heritage and resources in a way that excludes them. Those issues aside, it is clear that in the right hands (i.e., historic and cultural preservation organizations, and indigenous community development organizations.) the recognition of these sites can be used as a force for good to bring more opportunity for economically depressed communities.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/za)

name: How many people in South Afric
questionText: How many people in South Africa cook using stoves that don’t produce smoke?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data from the WHO is compiled using surveys and, where data is unavailable for a certain year, it is modeled. It also doesn’t take into account that households may have access to clean fuels but don’t use them because of their high costs. Also, homes that report using clean fuels may continue to use biomass as secondary energy sources. The data uncertainties are why we created large differences between the three answer options and use “around”, "close to" and "more then" instead of an exact number. We also consulted three independent experts who agreed that  the source of the data represent the most accurate picture of how things are when it comes to the use of clean cooking fuels and technology in the world.

Source link: [WHO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS?locations=ZA)

name: How many people in Somalia hav
questionText: How many people in Somalia have some access to electricity?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question, the source we use is The Energy Progress Report, which tracks the progress of SDG 7.  The term “access” is defined differently in all their underlying sources. In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/somalia)

name: How many babies in Somalia wer
questionText: How many babies in Somalia were vaccinated against some disease in 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/topics/indicator-groups/indicator-group-details/GHO/immunization-coverage-estimates)

name: How many vacation rentals in S
questionText: How many vacation rentals in Somalia are listed on Airbnb?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
We got this information from Airbnb's website in March 2022. There may be many more than 300 properties but when there is Airbnb just lists 300+ as the maximum no matter the country.

Source link: [Airbnb](https://www.airbnb.com/)

name: What was the life expectancy o
questionText: What was the life expectancy of a baby born in Somalia, in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Life expectancy is the number of years the average newborn in a population can expect to live if mortality rates in that year continue for the rest of a person’s life. For this question, we have used data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)'s 2019 Global Burden of Disease Study, which are estimates. This data is not collected annually (usually once every 10 years or so) and, as such, some of the countries’ figures may be slightly outdated. If data were available for every country for this year it is quite likely the average life expectancy would be even higher. 

Source link: [IHME](http://ihmeuw.org/5cy0)

name: In Sierra Leone, of all childr
questionText: In Sierra Leone, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2016?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR?locations=SL)

name: How much of all the money earn
questionText: How much of all the money earned in the Seychelles comes from agriculture, forestry and fishing?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The share of the world’s economy which is made up of agriculture, fishing and forestry is only 5%, because almost all money made today comes from services and manufacturing. This is based on national accounts data which is of poorer quality in poorer countries where the informal sector is larger. Over the last 200 years, most countries increased their incomes and as they did they have followed very similar declines of agriculture as a share of their economies. It’s hard to know exactly what the global percentage was at the start of the industrial revolution, but probably around 50%. That’s where a few extremely poor countries still are today.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS?locations=SC)

name: Is Senegal a low-, middle-, or
questionText: Is Senegal a low-, middle-, or high-income country?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The World Bank categorizes countries as low-, middle- or high-income countries based on gross national income per person. This is calculated using the World Bank Atlas method. In 2022, a country was classified as low-income with an average income of $1,045 or less in 2020; lower middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $1,046 and $4,095; upper middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $4,096 and $12,695; high-income economies are those with a GNI per capita of $12,696 or more.

Source link: [World Bank](https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org/knowledgebase/articles/906519-world-bank-country-and-lending-groups)

dataSourceLinkLongText:

name: In terms of representative pub
questionText: In terms of representative public institutions and fundamental freedoms, in 2021 São Tomé and Princípe scored:
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The ratings we use come from the non-profit group Civicus, which is a network of organizations at the local, national, regional and international levels. Civicus says of its methodology: "The CIVICUS Monitor combines data from a range of sources. Through a series of standard calculations and verification checks, we produce a guiding score for each country that we use to assign ratings on the state of civic space. Civic space is defined as the respect in law and practice for the freedoms of association, peaceful assembly and expression. Built into each of the three core freedoms is the understanding that a state has a duty to protect civil society, and must go beyond simply refraining from interfering in citizens' enjoyment of their rights." To ensure that we are not misrepresnting the freedoms of a country we also double check the Civicus rating with other sources.

Source link: [Civicus](https://monitor.civicus.org/country/sao-tome-and-principe/)

name: Which sector contributes the m
questionText: Which sector contributes the most to São Tomé and Príncipe's economy?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Services in this case corresponds to ISIC divisions 50-99 includes value added in things such as wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, healthcare, and real estate. The data comes from a country's national accounts. Three independent experts we consulted for this question considered this data reliable and the best to use when it comes to this particular question.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.SRV.TOTL.ZS?locations=ST)

name: How many adults in Sao Tome an
questionText: How many adults in Sao Tome and Principe say they can read and write?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Literacy data is from UNESCO. Data quality varies between countries and generally it is less reliable in low-income countries. 
It has been collected using different methodologies in different countries. In some countries the people surveyed are asked if they can read a short text aloud. In many countries, though, people are just asked if they can read or sometimes only if they and the people they live with went to school. There is some evidence from studies that people do not read as well as they report themselves to and that, in some cases, going to school may not mean a person is what we might consider to be literate. These doubts should not stop us recognizing the overall trend, that more mem, women and children have more years of education and more people say they can read than ever before. 
We have put big differences between our three answer options to ensure our correct answer is more correct than the other two.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.LITR.ZS?locations=ST)

In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/namibia)

name: How many babies in Namibia wer
questionText: How many babies in Namibia were vaccinated against some disease in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/topics/indicator-groups/indicator-group-details/GHO/immunization-coverage-estimates)

name: In Namibia, of all children ag
questionText: In Namibia, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2018?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [Source: UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR?locations=NA)

name: How many people (>15 years) in
questionText: How many people over the age of 15 in Namibia have a mobile money account?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use comes from the World Bank's Findex report in which around 1,000 people are surveyed across 144 countries. Three independent experts recognized this as being a reliable source, although the data can be quite old (the latest report is from 2017). That means, though, the number of people with mobile money accounts is likely to be higher than in our correct answer and also ensures  that the answer we have is likely to be the most correct. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=1228)

name: What is the biggest source of
questionText: What is the biggest source of electricity production in Namibia?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we used information from the International Energy Agency (IEA). Independent experts we contacted agreed that it is generally acknowledged that the most comprehensive and reliable source of information are the IEA's World Energy Outlook reports.

Source link: [IEA](https://www.iea.org/data-and-statistics?country=NAMIBIA&fuel=Energy%20supply&indicator=ElecGenByFuel)

name: When did Mozambique have its f
questionText: When did Mozambique have its first female prime minister?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
We used Wikipedia to find this information originally, before cross-checking with othe sources.

name: How much of Mozambique is barr
questionText: How much of Mozambique is barren land, with bare soil, sand and rocks?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). It defines barren land as "any geographical area dominated by natural abiotic surfaces (bare soil, sand, rocks, etc.) where the natural vegetation is absent or nearly absent (i.e. cover is less than 2 per cent). The class includes areas regularly flooded by inland water (lake shores, river banks, salt flats, etc.). It excludes coastal areas
affected by the tidal movement of saltwater." It compiles this information from publicly available maps from two different sources of satellite data. It is hard to define land completely accurately and that is why we have big differences between our answer options and don't give a precise number, choosing instead to use "less than" or "around".

Source link: [FAO](http://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/LC/visualize)

name: Of all the primary school teac
questionText: Of all the primary school teachers in Mozambique, how many have had teacher training?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from UNESCO. When it comes to issues around this data, one is that there is no global definition for what constitutes an academically trained teacher so each country has a slightly different definition. Also, a trained teacher is not necessarily the same as a qualified teacher. Plus, national standards regarding teacher qualifications and pedagogical skills may vary. This means estimates are dependent on the policy of each country and affect the final number.  The variable does not take into account the varying experience and status of teachers or how they were trained and what they have at their disposal when teaching (materials, classroom conditions etc) which are all factors that affect the quality of teaching and learning. Finally, some teachers without formal training may have acquired equivalent pedagogical skills through professional experience. Despite these concerns, three independent experts we contacted say they trust this data. We also try to counter these caveats by putting large differences between the answer options. 

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TCAQ.ZS?locations=1W-MZ)

name: Is Mauritius a low-, middle-,
questionText: Is Mauritius a low-, middle-, or high-income country?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The World Bank categorizes countries as low-, middle- or high-income countries based on gross national income per person. This is calculated using the World Bank Atlas method. In 2022, a country was classified as low-income with an average income of $1,045 or less in 2020; lower middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $1,046 and $4,095; upper middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $4,096 and $12,695; high-income economies are those with a GNI per capita of $12,696 or more.

Source link: [World Bank](https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org/knowledgebase/articles/906519-world-bank-country-and-lending-groups)

name: When did women first get the r
questionText: When did women first get the right to vote in Mauritius?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
We use information for this question from the the IPU, which is the global organization of national parliaments and recognized by the independent experts we contacted as a reliable source of information.

Source link: [IPU](http://archive.ipu.org/wmn-e/suffrage.htm)

name: What share of Mauritius' roads
questionText: What share of Mauritius' roads are paved?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use in this question comes from the CIA Factbook. Some of the data can be quite old and there is a lack of transparency about the data used which is why we try to cross-check it with other sources, keep big differences between the answer options and use the less specific "around" or "more than" for the correct answers.

Source link: [CIA](https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/field/roadways)

name: How many people in Mauritius c
questionText: How many people in Mauritius cook using stoves that don’t produce smoke?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data from the WHO is compiled using surveys and, where data is unavailable for a certain year, it is modeled. It also doesn’t take into account that households may have access to clean fuels but don’t use them because of their high costs. Also, homes that report using clean fuels may continue to use biomass as secondary energy sources. The data uncertainties are why we created large differences between the three answer options and use “around”, "close to" and "more then" instead of an exact number. We also consulted three independent experts who agreed that  the source of the data represent the most accurate picture of how things are when it comes to the use of clean cooking fuels and technology in the world.

Source link: [WHO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.CFT.ACCS.ZS?locations=MU)

name: How many firms in Mauritania u
questionText: How many firms in Mauritania use email to interact with clients or suppliers?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we use data from the Enterprise Survey by the World Bank. This is based on interviews conducted during the period 2009 to 2020 with tens of thousands of businesses with 5 or more employees in the manufacturing and service sectors in 144 countries. Firms with 100% government/state ownership are not included. The number of businesses per country ranges from 150 in small countries, to nearly 2000 in large countries. Because the data is based on a small sample of all companies in the world, there is a large margin of error which we take into consideration by putting big differences between the correct answer and the two wrong options. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://tcdata360.worldbank.org/indicators/etrade.pct.email?country=MRT&indicator=272&viz=bar_chart&years=2014)

name: How much of all the money earn
questionText: How much of all the money earned in Malawi comes from agriculture, forestry and fishing?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The share of the world’s economy which is made up of agriculture, fishing and forestry is only 5%, because almost all money made today comes from services and manufacturing. This is based on national accounts data which is of poorer quality in poorer countries where the informal sector is larger. Over the last 200 years, most countries increased their incomes and as they did they have followed very similar declines of agriculture as a share of their economies. It’s hard to know exactly what the global percentage was at the start of the industrial revolution, but probably around 50%. That’s where a few extremely poor countries still are today.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS?locations=MW)

name: How many babies in Malawi were
questionText: How many babies in Malawi were born with a trained health worker present in 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This data is complied by the World Health Organization and Unicef. The number we use is based on the most recent data. Data from some countries is more reliable than from others. Different countries also use very different criteria for what is a “trained” health worker. To account for this we use the correct option “more than” rather than using a specific number, to ensure we do not overestimate progress. Since 2004, we have known how many skilled health workers attend births but not their quality. After 2004, there was an increase in births attended by skilled workers, and even though there was a lot of progress, the decline in maternal mortality didn’t reach the 75% by 2015 that was stated in the Millennium Development Goals (The decrease in maternal mortality ratio from 2000 to 2017 was 38%. This was addressed in 2018, with a newer definition of who is a skilled health worker, which has stricter standards. Our data doesn’t yet take this new definition into account as most of the data was collected before 2018. Due to the issue around the definition of “skilled” we tweaked the question to say “trained” health worker instead, as the definition the data uses still meets that criteria.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://data.unicef.org/topic/maternal-health/delivery-care/)

name: How much of the land area of M
questionText: How much of the land area of Malawi is protected?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This is a trickier thing to measure that it might first appear. The source we use (Protected Planet) is a good respresentation of what land is designated as protected by governments but the problem is countries choose which land they decide to protect. This can end up being ‘the land that nobody wants’ that they protect just to meet targets. There’s also no evidence that countries spend any more time, money or effort, conserving this land (which is sort of the point). It can become more of an exercise in box ticking than conservation, which is why we have avoided asking questions about countries where we know there to be particular issues.

Source link: [Protected Planet](https://www.protectedplanet.net/country/MWI)

questionText: How much of all the money earned in Madagascar comes from agriculture, forestry and fishing?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The share of the world’s economy which is made up of agriculture, fishing and forestry is only 5%, because almost all money made today comes from services and manufacturing. This is based on national accounts data which is of poorer quality in poorer countries where the informal sector is larger. Over the last 200 years, most countries increased their incomes and as they did they have followed very similar declines of agriculture as a share of their economies. It’s hard to know exactly what the global percentage was at the start of the industrial revolution, but probably around 50%. That’s where a few extremely poor countries still are today.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS?locations=MG)

name: During the past 5 years, women
questionText: During the past 5 years, women held 25% of all seats in national parliaments worldwide. What was the number in Madagascar?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Our correct figure is an average across both lower and upper chambers of parliament between 2017-2022. This figure will change as elections are held. We chose to have an average across both chambers of parliament despite the upper houses having different levels of power in different countries. It’s worth noting that being represented in the parliament does not automatically transfer into female contribution and engagement as there sometimes can be other obstacles.
We consulted six independent experts for this question who all agreed that the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) data is extremely reliable.

Source link: [IPU](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QE30QKC-uMbvUlYxLDaZpTVe59ooO0Rz9IC-dbIDQJg/edit#gid=569008169)

name: How many adults in Madagascar
questionText: How many adults in Madagascar say they can read and write?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Literacy data is from UNESCO. Data quality varies between countries and generally it is less reliable in low-income countries. 
It has been collected using different methodologies in different countries. In some countries the people surveyed are asked if they can read a short text aloud. In many countries, though, people are just asked if they can read or sometimes only if they and the people they live with went to school. There is some evidence from studies that people do not read as well as they report themselves to and that, in some cases, going to school may not mean a person is what we might consider to be literate. These doubts should not stop us recognizing the overall trend, that more mem, women and children have more years of education and more people say they can read than ever before. 
We have put big differences between our three answer options to ensure our correct answer is more correct than the other two.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.LITR.ZS?locations=MG)

name: How many airports in Madagasca
questionText: How many airports in Madagascar have paved runways?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The answer for this question comes from the World Food Programme's Logistics Capacity Assessment tool. They say that assessments are conducted in a given country every two years, mainly by WFP logistics staff and also by staff from other humanitarian organisations or private sector partners

Source link: [WFP](https://dlca.logcluster.org/display/public/DLCA/2.2+Madagascar+Aviation)

name: How many people in Liberia hav
questionText: How many people in Liberia have some access to electricity?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question, the source we use is The Energy Progress Report, which tracks the progress of SDG 7.  The term “access” is defined differently in all their underlying sources. In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/liberia)

name: How many babies in Liberia wer
questionText: How many babies in Liberia were vaccinated against some disease in 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/themes/topics/indicator-groups/indicator-group-details/GHO/immunization-coverage-estimates)

name: In Liberia, of all children ag
questionText: In Liberia, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2017?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [Source: UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR?locations=LR)

name: How many companies in Liberia
questionText: How many companies in Liberia have a woman as one of their main owners?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we use data from the Enterprise Survey by the World Bank. This is based on interviews conducted during the period 2009 to 2020 with tens of thousands of businesses with 5 or more employees in the manufacturing and service sectors in 144 countries. Firms with 100% government/state ownership are not included. The number of businesses per country ranges from 150 in small countries, to nearly 2000 in large countries. Because the data is based on a small sample of all companies in the world, there is a large margin of error which we take into consideration by putting big differences between the correct answer and the two wrong options.

Source link: [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IC.FRM.FEMO.ZS?locations=LR)

name: How many airports are there in
questionText: How many airports are there in Lesotho?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
OurAirports relies on contributors to crowdsource airport locations. Because of that, we cross-check their numbers with those on the CIA factbook (which are often much lower). We typically use the lower number and say "more than" so we do not overestimate development.

Source link: [OurAirports](https://ourairports.com/countries/LS/)

name: In Lesotho in 2018, how many b
questionText: In Lesotho in 2018, how many babies were born with a trained health worker present?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This data is complied by the World Health Organization and Unicef. The number we use is based on the most recent data. Data from some countries is more reliable than from others. Different countries also use very different criteria for what is a “trained” health worker. To account for this we use the correct option “more than” rather than using a specific number, to ensure we do not overestimate progress. Since 2004, we have known how many skilled health workers attend births but not their quality. After 2004, there was an increase in births attended by skilled workers, and even though there was a lot of progress, the decline in maternal mortality didn’t reach the 75% by 2015 that was stated in the Millennium Development Goals (The decrease in maternal mortality ratio from 2000 to 2017 was 38%. This was addressed in 2018, with a newer definition of who is a skilled health worker, which has stricter standards. Our data doesn’t yet take this new definition into account as most of the data was collected before 2018. Due to the issue around the definition of “skilled” we tweaked the question to say “trained” health worker instead, as the definition the data uses still meets that criteria.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://data.unicef.org/topic/maternal-health/delivery-care/)

name: How many houses and apartments
questionText: How many houses and apartments in Lesotho are listed as vacation rentals on Airbnb?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
We got this information from Airbnb's website in March 2022. There may be many more than 300 properties but when there is Airbnb just lists 300+ as the maximum no matter the country.

Source link: [Airbnb](https://www.airbnb.com/s/Lesotho/homes?tab_id=home_tab&refinement_paths%5B%5D=%2Fhomes&flexible_trip_dates%5B%5D=april&flexible_trip_dates%5B%5D=may&flexible_trip_lengths%5B%5D=weekend_trip&date_picker_type=calendar&query=Lesotho&place_id=ChIJ64xf1idIjB4R)

name: How many people (16 years and
questionText: How many people (16 years and older) in Kenya have a mobile money account?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use comes from the World Bank's Findex report in which around 1,000 people are surveyed across 144 countries. Three independent experts recognized this as being a reliable source, although the data can be quite old (the latest report is from 2017). That means, though, the number of people with mobile money accounts is likely to be higher than in our correct answer and also ensures  that the answer we have is likely to be the most correct. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=1228)

name: What is the biggest source of
questionText: What is the biggest source of electricity production in Kenya?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we used information from the International Energy Agency (IEA). Independent experts we contacted agreed that it is generally acknowledged that the most comprehensive and reliable source of information are the IEA's World Energy Outlook reports.

Source link: [IEA](https://www.iea.org/data-and-statistics?country=PARAGUAY&fuel=Energy%20supply&indicator=Electricity%20generation%20by%20source)

name: When did Guinea-Bissau become
questionText: When did Guinea-Bissau become a member of the United Nations?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Guinea-Bissau became a member of the United Nations on 17th September 1974.

Source link: [United Nations](https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/646836?ln=en)

name: How much of Guinea-Bissau is p
questionText: How much of Guinea-Bissau is protected land, such as national parks?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This is a trickier thing to measure that it might forst appear. The source we use (Protected Planet) is a good respresentation of what land is designated as protected by governments but the problem is countries choose which land they decide to protect. This can end up being ‘the land that nobody wants’ that they protect just to meet targets. There’s also no evidence that countries spend any more time, money or effort, conserving this land (which is sort of the point). It can become more of an exercise in box ticking than conservation, which is why we have avoided asking questions about countries where we know there to be particular issues.

Source link: [UNEP Protected Planet](https://www.protectedplanet.net/country/GNB)

name: How many municipalities in Gui
questionText: How many municipalities in Guinea are part of UNICEF’s Child Friendly Cities Initiative?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The main objective from UNICEF is that these cities, towns and municipalities implement the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. They have a set of criteria but whether they are actually determinants and how they are assessed are questioned by independent experts we contacted. A concern raised by one was that a whole city does not have to be part of the initiative, only a part of it like a municipality. The data collection and monitoring is different in different parts of the world. Additionally in some cases it may only be a matter of calling themselves child friendly, the label does not necessarily reflect the reality for the children living there. Another issue is that being part of the initiative might require some collaboration with UNICEF. There is however no other comparative measure when it comes to child friendly cities so this is the best one out there. UNICEF is seen as a reliable and trusted source by the experts.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://childfriendlycities.org/)

name: Of all the primary school teac
questionText: Of all the primary school teachers in Guinea, how many have had teacher training?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from UNESCO. When it comes to issues around this data, one is that there is no global definition for what constitutes an academically trained teacher so each country has a slightly different definition. Also, a trained teacher is not necessarily the same as a qualified teacher. Plus, national standards regarding teacher qualifications and pedagogical skills may vary. This means estimates are dependent on the policy of each country and affect the final number.  The variable does not take into account the varying experience and status of teachers or how they were trained and what they have at their disposal when teaching (materials, classroom conditions etc) which are all factors that affect the quality of teaching and learning. Finally, some teachers without formal training may have acquired equivalent pedagogical skills through professional experience. Despite these concerns, three independent experts we contacted say they trust this data. We also try to counter these caveats by putting large differences between the answer options. 

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TCAQ.ZS?locations=GN)

name: What was the life expectancy o
questionText: What was the life expectancy of a newborn child in Guinea in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Life expectancy is the number of years the average newborn in a population can expect to live if mortality rates in that year continue for the rest of a person’s life. For this question, we have used data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)'s 2019 Global Burden of Disease Study, which are estimates. This data is not collected annually (usually once every 10 years or so) and, as such, some of the countries’ figures may be slightly outdated. If data were available for every country for this year it is quite likely the average life expectancy would be even higher. 

Source link: [IHME](http://ihmeuw.org/5cy0)

name: How many houses or apartments

dataSourceLinkLongText:

Source link: [Airbnb](https://www.airbnb.com/s/Guinea/homes?adults=1&place_id=ChIJP5XOvCGzAQ8R9i1a18t7c-g&refinement_paths%5B%5D=%2Fhomes)

These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/countries?countrycriteria%5Bcountry%5D%5B%5D=KHM)

name: In The Gambia, of all children
questionText: In The Gambia, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2018?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [Source: UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR)

name: How much of all the money earn
questionText: How much of all the money earned in The Gambia comes from agriculture, forestry and fishing?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The share of the world’s economy which is made up of agriculture, fishing and forestry is only 5%, because almost all money made today comes from services and manufacturing. This is based on national accounts data which is of poorer quality in poorer countries where the informal sector is larger. Over the last 200 years, most countries increased their incomes and as they did they have followed very similar declines of agriculture as a share of their economies. It’s hard to know exactly what the global percentage was at the start of the industrial revolution, but probably around 50%. That’s where a few extremely poor countries still are today.

Source link: [National Accounts](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NV.AGR.TOTL.ZS?locations=GM)

name: Of all the primary school teac
questionText: Of all the primary school teachers in The Gambia, how many have had teacher training?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use for this question comes from UNESCO. When it comes to issues around this data, one is that there is no global definition for what constitutes an academically trained teacher so each country has a slightly different definition. Also, a trained teacher is not necessarily the same as a qualified teacher. Plus, national standards regarding teacher qualifications and pedagogical skills may vary. This means estimates are dependent on the policy of each country and affect the final number.  The variable does not take into account the varying experience and status of teachers or how they were trained and what they have at their disposal when teaching (materials, classroom conditions etc) which are all factors that affect the quality of teaching and learning. Finally, some teachers without formal training may have acquired equivalent pedagogical skills through professional experience. Despite these concerns, three independent experts we contacted say they trust this data. We also try to counter these caveats by putting large differences between the answer options. 

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TCAQ.ZS?locations=1W-GM)

name: How many babies in Gabon were
questionText: How many babies in Gabon were vaccinated against some disease in 2019 (before the Coronavirus pandemic)?

The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.

To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/countries?countrycriteria%5Bcountry%5D%5B%5D=KHM)

name: When was the first time Gabon
questionText: When was the first time Gabon had a woman as leader of the country?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
We used Wikipedia to find this information originally, before cross-checking with other sources.

Source link: [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_elected_and_appointed_female_heads_of_state_and_government)

name: How many people in Gabon have
questionText: How many people in Gabon have some access to electricity?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question, the source we use is The Energy Progress Report, which tracks the progress of SDG 7.  The term “access” is defined differently in all their underlying sources. In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/gabon)

name: In Gabon, how many people olde
questionText: In Gabon, how many people older than 15 have a mobile money account?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use comes from the World Bank's Findex report in which around 1,000 people are surveyed across 144 countries. Three independent experts recognized this as being a reliable source, although the data can be quite old (the latest report is from 2017). That means, though, the number of people with mobile money accounts is likely to be higher than in our correct answer and also ensures  that the answer we have is likely to be the most correct. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=1228)

name: How much of Gabon is protected
questionText: How much of Gabon is protected land, such as national parks?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This is a trickier thing to measure that it might forst appear. The source we use (Protected Planet) is a good respresentation of what land is designated as protected by governments but the problem is countries choose which land they decide to protect. This can end up being ‘the land that nobody wants’ that they protect just to meet targets. There’s also no evidence that countries spend any more time, money or effort, conserving this land (which is sort of the point). It can become more of an exercise in box ticking than conservation, which is why we have avoided asking questions about countries where we know there to be particular issues.

Source link: [UNEP Protected Planet](https://www.protectedplanet.net/)

name: What was the life expectancy i
questionText: What was the life expectancy in Gabon in 2019?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Life expectancy is the number of years the average newborn in a population can expect to live if mortality rates in that year continue for the rest of a person’s life. For this question, we have used data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)'s 2019 Global Burden of Disease Study, which are estimates. This data is not collected annually (usually once every 10 years or so) and, as such, some of the countries’ figures may be slightly outdated. If data were available for every country for this year it is quite likely the average life expectancy would be even higher. 

Source link: [IHME](http://ihmeuw.org/5cy0)

name: How many adults in Equatorial
questionText: How many adults in Equatorial Guinea say they can read and write?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
Literacy data is from UNESCO. Data quality varies between countries and generally it is less reliable in low-income countries. 
It has been collected using different methodologies in different countries. In some countries the people surveyed are asked if they can read a short text aloud. In many countries, though, people are just asked if they can read or sometimes only if they and the people they live with went to school. There is some evidence from studies that people do not read as well as they report themselves to and that, in some cases, going to school may not mean a person is what we might consider to be literate. These doubts should not stop us recognizing the overall trend, that more mem, women and children have more years of education and more people say they can read than ever before. 
We have put big differences between our three answer options to ensure our correct answer is more correct than the other two.

Source link: [UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.LITR.ZS?locations=GQ)

name: How many babies in Equatorial
questionText: How many babies in Equatorial Guinea were vaccinated against some disease in 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). This data represents the chidren who received two doses of measles containing vaccine (MCV2) in a given year, according to the nationally recommended schedule. We use the most current data. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number.

Source link: [WHO-UNICEF](https://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/countries?countrycriteria%5Bcountry%5D%5B%5D=GNQ)

questionText: What is the biggest source of electricity production in Ethiopia?
dataSourceLinkLongText:

dataSourceLinkLongText:

name: In Eswatini, how many babies a
questionText: In Eswatini, how many babies are born with a trained health worker present (before the pandemic)?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This data is complied by the World Health Organization and Unicef. The number we use is based on the most recent data. Data from some countries is more reliable than from others. Different countries also use very different criteria for what is a “trained” health worker. To account for this we use the correct option “more than” rather than using a specific number, to ensure we do not overestimate progress. Since 2004, we have known how many skilled health workers attend births but not their quality. After 2004, there was an increase in births attended by skilled workers, and even though there was a lot of progress, the decline in maternal mortality didn’t reach the 75% by 2015 that was stated in the Millennium Development Goals (The decrease in maternal mortality ratio from 2000 to 2017 was 38%. This was addressed in 2018, with a newer definition of who is a skilled health worker, which has stricter standards. Our data doesn’t yet take this new definition into account as most of the data was collected before 2018. Due to the issue around the definition of “skilled” we tweaked the question to say “trained” health worker instead, as the definition the data uses still meets that criteria.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://data.unicef.org/topic/maternal-health/delivery-care/)

name: How many companies in Eswatini
questionText: How many companies in Eswatini have a woman as one of their main owners?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we use data from the Enterprise Survey by the World Bank. This is based on interviews conducted during the period 2009 to 2020 with tens of thousands of businesses with 5 or more employees in the manufacturing and service sectors in 144 countries. Firms with 100% government/state ownership are not included. The number of businesses per country ranges from 150 in small countries, to nearly 2000 in large countries. Because the data is based on a small sample of all companies in the world, there is a large margin of error which we take into consideration by putting big differences between the correct answer and the two wrong options.

Source link: [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IC.FRM.FEMO.ZS?locations=SZ)

name: Is Eswatini (former Swaziland)
questionText: Is Eswatini (former Swaziland) a low-, middle-, or high-income country?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The World Bank categorizes countries as low-, middle- or high-income countries based on gross national income per person. This is calculated using the World Bank Atlas method. In 2022, a country was classified as low-income with an average income of $1,045 or less in 2020; lower middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $1,046 and $4,095; upper middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $4,096 and $12,695; high-income economies are those with a GNI per capita of $12,696 or more.

Source link: [World Bank](https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org/knowledgebase/articles/906519-world-bank-country-and-lending-groups)

The WHO estimates are based mainly on data from national administrative records and household surveys, such as the Expanded Programme on Immunization cluster survey, the UNICEF Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey, and the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS). These surveys assess the vaccination coverage among children aged 12-23 months who received a vaccination anytime before the survey.
Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

Source link: [Source: WHO](https://apps.who.int/immunization_monitoring/globalsummary/countries?countrycriteria%5Bcountry%5D%5B%5D=CIV)

name: In Cote d'Ivoire, of all child
questionText: In Cote d'Ivoire, of all children aged 7 to 11, how many went to school in 2018?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from UNESCO. The ages we use in the question refer to primary school age in that particular country (the ages people attend primary school differ slightly by country). The number used is the percentage of children of that age in the country who are enrolled in school. This number does not show actual school attendance or how many children drop out, just how many are signed up for school. Despite that limitation, five independent experts we contacted said this data is the best available. We also put in big differences between the three options so that the 'correct' answer we use is way more correct than the two other options.

Source link: [Source: UNESCO](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.PRM.TENR?locations=CI)

name: How many vacation rentals in C

name: How many people in the Côte d’
questionText: How many people in the Côte d’Ivoire have a mobile money account (of those older than 15)?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data we use comes from the World Bank's Findex report in which around 1,000 people are surveyed across 144 countries. Three independent experts recognized this as being a reliable source, although the data can be quite old (the latest report is from 2017). That means, though, the number of people with mobile money accounts is likely to be higher than in our correct answer and also ensures  that the answer we have is likely to be the most correct. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=1228)

name: How many people in the Democra
questionText: How many people in the Democratic Republic of the Congo have some access to electricity?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question, the source we use is The Energy Progress Report, which tracks the progress of SDG 7.  The term “access” is defined differently in all their underlying sources. In some extreme cases, households may experience an average of 60 power outages per week and still be listed as “having access to electricity”. We have made sure to avoid using data for countries where experts said the data is particularly unreliable
and we also use "more than" so we avoid using a specific number which may overstate progress. 

Source link: [ESMAP](https://trackingsdg7.esmap.org/country/democratic-republic-congo)

name: How many babies in the Democra
questionText: How many babies in the Democratic Republic of the Congo were vaccinated against some disease in 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The data comes from the Global Health Observatory data repository of the World Health Organization (WHO). Gapminder has compiled the estimates on the percentage of 1-year-old children who received nine different vaccinations (Haemophilus influenzae type B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, tuberculosis BCG, measles, pneumococcal disease, poliomyelitis and rotavirus) for the period 1980-2019 for countries and territories and average global immunization coverage. To avoid overestimating the share of children who have been vaccinated at least once, we use "more than" rather than a specific number

name: In the Democratic Republic of
questionText: In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, how many babies were born with a trained health worker present, before 2020?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This data is complied by the World Health Organization and Unicef. The number we use is based on the most recent data. Data from some countries is more reliable than from others. Different countries also use very different criteria for what is a “trained” health worker. To account for this we use the correct option “more than” rather than using a specific number, to ensure we do not overestimate progress. Since 2004, we have known how many skilled health workers attend births but not their quality. After 2004, there was an increase in births attended by skilled workers, and even though there was a lot of progress, the decline in maternal mortality didn’t reach the 75% by 2015 that was stated in the Millennium Development Goals (The decrease in maternal mortality ratio from 2000 to 2017 was 38%. This was addressed in 2018, with a newer definition of who is a skilled health worker, which has stricter standards. Our data doesn’t yet take this new definition into account as most of the data was collected before 2018. Due to the issue around the definition of “skilled” we tweaked the question to say “trained” health worker instead, as the definition the data uses still meets that criteria.

Source link: [UNICEF](https://data.unicef.org/topic/maternal-health/delivery-care/)

name: How much of the land area of C
questionText: How much of the land area of Chad is protected?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
This is a trickier thing to measure that it might forst appear. The source we use (Protected Planet) is a good representation of what land is designated as protected by governments but the problem is countries choose which land they decide to protect. This can end up being ‘the land that nobody wants’ that they protect just to meet targets. There’s also no evidence that countries spend any more time, money or effort, conserving this land (which is sort of the point). It can become more of an exercise in box ticking than conservation, which is why we have avoided asking questions about countries where we know there to be particular issues.

Source link: [UNEP Protected Planet](https://www.protectedplanet.net/country/TCD)

name: Is Cameroon a low-, middle-, o
questionText: Is Cameroon a low-, middle-, or high-income country?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The World Bank categorizes countries as low-, middle- or high-income countries based on gross national income per person. This is calculated using the World Bank Atlas method. In 2022, a country was classified as low-income with an average income of $1,045 or less in 2020; lower middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $1,046 and $4,095; upper middle-income economies are those with a GNI per capita between $4,096 and $12,695; high-income economies are those with a GNI per capita of $12,696 or more.

Source link: [World Bank](https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org/knowledgebase/articles/906519-world-bank-country-and-lending-groups)

name: How many companies in Cameroon
questionText: How many companies in Cameroon have a female top manager?
dataSourceLinkLongText:
For this question we use data from the Enterprise Survey by the World Bank. This is based on interviews conducted during the period 2009 to 2020 with tens of thousands of businesses with 5 or more employees in the manufacturing and service sectors in 144 countries. Firms with 100% government/state ownership are not included. The number of businesses per country ranges from 150 in small countries, to nearly 2000 in large countries. Because the data is based on a small sample of all companies in the world, there is a large margin of error which we take into consideration by putting big differences between the correct answer and the two wrong options. 

Source link: [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IC.FRM.FEMM.ZS?locations=CM)

name: In terms of representative pub
questionText: In terms of representative public institutions and fundamental freedoms, in 2021 Cabo Verde scored:
dataSourceLinkLongText:
The ratings we use come from the non-profit group Civicus, which is a network of organizations at the local, national, regional and international levels. Civicus says of its methodology: "The CIVICUS Monitor combines data from a range of sources. Through a series of standard calculations and verification checks, we produce a guiding score for each country that we use to assign ratings on the state of civic space. Civic space is defined as the respect in law and practice for the freedoms of association, peaceful assembly and expression. Built into each of the three core freedoms is the understanding that a state has a duty to protect civil society, and must go beyond simply refraining from interfering in citizens' enjoyment of their rights." To ensure that we are not misrepresnting the freedoms of a country we also double check the Civicus rating with other sources.

Source link: [Civicus](https://monitor.civicus.org/country/cape-verde/)
